results.title: Outer space
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description: Prolific Austrian avant-garde filmmaker and theorist, Peter Tscherkassky, reinvents a 1981 Barbara Hershey horror vehicle, leaving the original’s crystalline surface intact only to violently shatter its narrative illusion. Sounds of crickets, static and distorted music give way to explosions, screams, and garbled voices. The actress’ face multiplies across the screen as the frame is invaded by sprocket holes, an optical soundtrack, and flashes of solarized imagery.
results.description: Prolific Austrian avant-garde filmmaker and theorist, Peter Tscherkassky, reinvents a 1981 Barbara Hershey horror vehicle, leaving the original’s crystalline surface intact only to violently shatter its narrative illusion. results.title: L'Arrivee = The Arrival
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description:
‘L’Arrivee’ is Tscherkassky’s second homage to the Lumiere-brothers. First you see the arrival of the film itself, which shows the arrival of a train at a station. But that train collides with a second train, causing a violent crash, which leads us to an unexpected third arrival, the arrival of a beautiful woman, the happy-end.

Reduced to two minutes, ‘L’Arrivee’ gives a brief, but exact summary of what cinematography (after its arrival with Lumieres train) has made into an enduring presence of our visual environment: violence, emotions. Or, as an anonymous American housewife (cited by T. W. Adorno) used to describe Hollywood’s version of life: ‘Getting into trouble and out of it again.’

results.title: Oxley Shire Hall
results.brief_description: Interview with local resident Janet Heath about the rebuilding of the historic Oxley Shire Hall (one of the oldest buildings in the area) by the local community. Includes internal and external shots of the Hall.

results.title: The Guan Yin Temple
results.brief_description: In this interview, Ralph Beh - a curator at the Golden Dragon Museum in Bendigo dicusses the history and significance of the remarkable murals that adorn the inner walls of the Guan Yin temple on the museum’s grounds.

results.title: Growing up in Bendigo
results.brief_description: Bendigo - short MTV style doco compiled from short interviews with teenagers on the streets of Bendigo. Subject matter includes how they feel about living in Bendigo, their hopes, aspirations, and whether they would like to stay in the town they grew up in as adults

results.title: The Golden dragons
results.brief_description: Bendigo - Bendigo’s annual Easter parade has featured the Dragon and Lion dancers from the Bendigo Chinese Association for over 100 years. This mini documentary explores how this historical tradition has helped shape the identities of the dancers and features interviews combined with footage of their colourful and exciting dance held at dusk at the Dragons’ spiritual home - Bendigo’s Golden Dragon Museum of Australia

results.title: Friends of the Bendigo Botanical Gardens
results.brief_description: Bendigo is better known for its old historic buildings than its heritage listed Botanic Gardens. Jan Orr, Rodney Orr and Glenys Anthony, members of the Friends of the Bendigo Botanic Gardens, talk about the history and some of the features of the Conservatory Gardens, including the rose garden and the fernery. The aim of the “Friends” group is to promote, protect and restore Bendigo’s heritage listed gardens.

results.title: Dennis O'Hoy: Bendigo Born and Bred
results.brief_description: Interview for the MAP project with lifelong Bendigo resident, Dennis O’Hoy, about his family history in the area, and his great love of, and identification with, the place where he lives.
